name: Parser

unions.name: Parser
unions.comment:
A `Parser a` is an instruction for how to take some input text and turn it
into an `a` value.

aliases.name: Error
aliases.comment:
Describes an error during parsing, i.e. what caused a parser to fail, and at
what position into the input text it failed.
aliases.type: { message : String.String, position : Basics.Int, context : Maybe.Maybe String.String }

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Create a parser that depends on the previous parser's result.

For example, you can support two different versions of a format if there's
a version number included:

    spec : Parser Spec
    spec =
        let
            specByVersion version =
                case version of
                    1 ->
                        v1

                    -- assume v1 is a Parser Spec
                    2 ->
                        v2

                    -- assume v2 is a Parser Spec
                    x ->
                        fail ("unknown spec version " ++ String.fromInt x)
        in
        string "version="
            |> followedBy int
            |> andThen specByVersion
values.type: (a -> Parser.Parser b) -> Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser b

values.name: anyChar
values.comment: Matches any character.

values.name: char
values.comment:
Matches a specific character.

    parse "hello" (char 'h') -- Ok 'h'

values.name: chomp
values.comment:
A parser that simply reads a specific number of characters from the
input.

    parse "xyz" (chomp 2) -- Ok "xy"

values.name: end
values.comment:
Matches the end of the input.

    char 'x'
        |> followedBy end
        |> parse "x" -- Ok ()

values.name: except
fail
followedBy
values.comment:
Create a parser that depends on a previous parser succeeding. Unlike
[`andThen`](#andThen), this does not preserve the value of the first parser,
so it's only useful when you want to discard that value.

    atMention : Parser String
    atMention =
        char '@'
            |> followedBy username
values.type: Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser b -> Parser.Parser a

values.name: grab
values.comment:
Grabs a value and feeds it into a function in a pipeline.

See [`into`](#into).
values.type: Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser (a -> b) -> Parser.Parser b

values.name: ignore
values.comment:
Ignores a matched value, preserving the previous value in a pipeline.

See [`into`](#into).
values.type: Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser b -> Parser.Parser b

values.name: inContext
values.comment: Sets the context of the parser. Useful for providing better error messages.

values.name: into
values.comment:
Start a parser pipeline that feeds values into a function.

Typically used to build up complex values.

    type Operation = Binary Int Char Int

    operation : Parser Operation
    operation =
        into Operation
            |> grab int
            |> ignore blanks
            |> grab (oneOf [ char '+', char '-', char '*' ])
            |> ignore blanks
            |> grab int

    parse "42 * 13" operation -- Binary 42 '*' 13

Here we feed three values into `Operation` while ignoring blank characters between
the values.

values.name: lazy
values.comment:
In order to support self-referential parsers, you need to introduce lazy
evaluation.

    type Tree = Leaf | Node Tree Tree

    tree : Parser Tree
    tree =
        oneOf [ leaf, node ]

    leaf : Parser Tree
    leaf =
        map (always Leaf) (char 'x')

    node : Parser Tree
    node =
        into Node
            |> ignore (char '@')
            |> grab (lazy (\_ -> tree))
            |> grab (lazy (\_ -> tree))

    parse "x" tree -- Ok Leaf
    parse "@x@xx" tree -- Ok (Node Leaf (Node Leaf Leaf))

Without `lazy`, this example would fail due to a circular reference.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Map the value of a parser.

    map (\x -> x * x) int

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Matches two parsers and combines the result.

    map2 (\x y -> (x, y)) anyChar anyChar
        |> parse "xy" -- Ok ('x', 'y')
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser b -> Parser.Parser c

values.name: matchedString
values.comment:
Maps a parser to include all the matched input as a String.

    matchedString (sequence [ word, string "@", word ])
        |> parse "hello@world!" -- Ok "hello@world"

values.name: maybe
values.comment:
Maybe match a value. If the parser succeeds with `x`, we'll succeed with
`Just x`. If if fails, we'll succeed with `Nothing`.

    parse "42" (maybe int) -- Just 42

    parse "hello" (maybe int) -- Nothing

values.name: oneOf
values.comment:
Matches one of a list of parsers.

    parse "y" (oneOf [ char 'x', char 'y' ]) -- Ok 'y'

values.name: oneOrMore
values.comment:
Matches one or more successive occurrences of a value. Fails if
there are no occurrences.

    parse "xxy" (oneOrMore (char 'x')) -- Ok [ 'x', 'x' ]

    parse "yyy" (oneOrMore (char 'x')) -- Err { message = "expected char `x`", position = 0 }

values.name: orElse
values.comment: Create a fallback for when a parser fails.
values.type: Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser a

values.name: parse
values.comment:
Parse an input string using a specific parser, returning a result containing
either the parsed value or an error.

    parse "xyz" (char 'x') -- Ok 'x'

    parse "xyz" (char 'w') -- Err { message = "expected char w", position = 0 }
values.type: String.String -> Parser.Parser a -> Result.Result Parser.Error a

values.name: repeat
values.comment:
Matches a specific number of occurrences of a parser, succeeding with a list
of values.

    parse "xxxx" (repeat 3 (char 'x')) -- Ok [ 'x', 'x', 'x' ]

values.name: separatedBy
values.comment:
Matches zero or more values separated by a specified parser.

    separatedBy (char ',') int
        |> parse "42,13,99" -- Ok [ 42, 13, 99 ]
values.type: Parser.Parser s -> Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser (List.List a)

values.name: sequence
values.comment:
Matches a sequence of parsers in turn, succeeding with a list of
their values if they _all_ succeed.

    parse "helloworld" (sequence [ string "hello", string "world" ]) -- Ok [ "hello", "world" ]

values.name: string
values.comment:
Matches a specific string.

    parse "hello world" (string "hello") -- Ok "hello"

values.name: stringWith
values.comment:
Turns a parser that returns a list of characters into a parser that
returns a String.

    parse "xyz" (stringWith (sequence [ char 'x', anyChar, char 'z' ])) -- Ok "xyz"

values.name: succeed
values.comment:
A parser that always succeeds with a specified value without reading any input.

    parse "xyz" (succeed 42) -- Ok 42

values.name: until
values.comment:
Matches zero or more values until a "stop" parser matches.

    char '['
        |> followedBy (until (char ']') anyChar)
        |> parse "[abc]" -- Ok [ 'a', 'b', 'c' ]
values.type: Parser.Parser a -> Parser.Parser b -> Parser.Parser (List.List b)

values.name: when
values.comment:
Matches a character if some predicate holds.

    parse "123" (when Char.isDigit) -- Ok '1'

values.name: withError
values.comment: Use the specified error message when the parser fails. string "" |> withError "expected closing tag"

values.name: zeroOrMore
values.comment:
Matches zero or more successive occurrences of a value. Succeeds with
an empty list if there are no occurrences.

    parse "xxy" (zeroOrMore (char 'x')) -- Ok [ 'x', 'x' ]

    parse "yyy" (zeroOrMore (char 'x')) -- Ok []

name: Parser.Common

values.name: alpha
values.comment: Matches an alphabetic character.

values.name: alphaNum
values.comment: Matches an alphanumeric character.

values.name: blank
values.comment: Matches either a space or a tab.

values.name: blanks
values.comment: Matches zero or more [`blank`](#blank) characters.

values.name: digit
values.comment: Matches a digit, e.g. `8`.

values.name: float
values.comment:
Matches a float.

    parse "4.2" float -- Ok 4.2

values.name: int
values.comment:
Matches an integer.

    parse "42" int -- Ok 42

values.name: iso8601
values.comment:
Matches valid [ISO8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601)
datetimes.

values.name: lower
values.comment: Matches a lowercase alphabetic characters, e.g. `z`.

values.name: newline
values.comment: Matches a newline character.

values.name: space
values.comment: Matches the space character, \`\`.

values.name: tab
values.comment: Matches the tab character, `\t`.

values.name: upper
values.comment: Matches an uppercase alphabetic characters, e.g. `A`.

values.name: word
values.comment:
Matches a "word", comprised of alphanumeric characters and `_`.

    parse "hello world" word -- Ok "hello"
